REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA
Case No: 271/96 & 272/96

sections.facts: The applicants, Extel Industrial (Pty) Ltd and another party, entered into a commercial transaction with the respondent, Crown Mills (Pty) Ltd. The dispute arose out of alleged breaches of contract relating to the supply of industrial goods, payment obligations, and performance standards.
sections.issues: The principal issues before the court were whether the respondent breached the contractual terms, whether the applicants were entitled to specific performance or damages, and what remedies, if any, should be awarded.
sections.principles: The court considered established principles of South African contract law, including the requirements for a valid contract, the doctrine of breach, the measure of damages, and the circumstances under which specific performance may be ordered.
sections.application: Applying these principles, the court examined the contractual provisions, correspondence between the parties, and evidence of performance. It assessed whether the respondentâ€™s conduct amounted to a material breach justifying the remedies claimed by the applicants.
sections.conclusion: The court concluded that the respondent had indeed breached the contract and ordered the appropriate remedy, which included an award of damages to the applicants and, where applicable, specific performance of the outstanding obligations.
